text: The Song of Songs, which is Solomon’s.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“May he kiss me with the kisses of his mouth!
For your love is sweeter than wine.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Draw me after you and let’s run together!
The king has brought me into his chambers.”
“We will rejoice in you and be joyful;
We will praise your love more than wine.
Rightly do they love you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I am black and beautiful,
You daughters of Jerusalem,
Like the tents of Kedar,
Like the curtains of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not stare at me because I am dark,
For the sun has tanned me.
My mother’s sons were angry with me;
They made me caretaker of the vineyards,
But I have not taken care of my own vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell me, you whom my soul loves,
Where do you pasture your flock,
Where do you have it lie down at noon?
For why should I be like one who veils herself
Beside the flocks of your companions?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If you yourself do not know,
Most beautiful among women,
Go out on the trail of the flock,
And pasture your young goats
By the tents of the shepherds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“To me, my darling, you are like
My mare among the chariots of Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your cheeks are delightful with jewelry,
Your neck with strings of beads.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“We will make for you jewelry of gold
With beads of silver.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“While the king was at his table,
My perfume gave forth its fragrance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is to me a pouch of myrrh
Which lies all night between my breasts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is to me a cluster of henna blossoms
In the vineyards of Engedi.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How beautiful you are, my darling,
How beautiful you are!
Your eyes are like doves.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How handsome you are, my beloved,
And so delightful!
Indeed, our bed is luxuriant!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The beams of our house are cedars,
Our rafters, junipers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I am the rose of Sharon,
The lily of the valleys.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Like a lily among the thorns,
So is my darling among the young women.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Like an apple tree among the trees of the forest,
So is my beloved among the young men.
In his shade I took great delight and sat down,
And his fruit was sweet to my taste.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has brought me to his banquet hall,
And his banner over me is love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Refresh me with raisin cakes,
Sustain me with apples,
Because I am lovesick.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His left hand is under my head,
And his right hand embraces me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Swear to me, you daughters of Jerusalem,
By the gazelles or by the does of the field,
That you will not disturb or awaken my love
Until she pleases.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen! My beloved!
Behold, he is coming,
Leaping on the mountains,
Jumping on the hills!
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved is like a gazelle or a young stag.
Behold, he is standing behind our wall,
He is looking through the windows,
He is peering through the lattice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My beloved responded and said to me,
‘Arise, my darling, my beautiful one,
And come along.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For behold, the winter is past,
The rain is over and gone.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The fig tree has ripened its fruit,
And the vines in blossom have given forth their fragrance.
Arise, my darling, my beautiful one,
And come along!’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My dove, in the clefts of the rock,
In the hiding place of the mountain pathway,
Let me see how you look,
Let me hear your voice;
For your voice is pleasant,
And you look delightful.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Catch the foxes for us,
The little foxes that are ruining the vineyards,
While our vineyards are in blossom.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My beloved is mine, and I am his;
He pastures his flock among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Until the cool of the day, when the shadows flee,
Turn, my beloved, and be like a gazelle
Or a young stag on the mountains of Bether.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
‘I must arise now and go around in the city;
In the streets and in the public squares
I must seek him whom my soul loves.’
I sought him but did not find him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchmen who make the rounds in the city found me,
And I said, ‘Have you seen him whom my soul loves?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hardly had I left them
When I found him whom my soul loves;
I held on to him and would not let him go
Until I had brought him to my mother’s house,
And into the room of her who conceived me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Swear to me, you daughters of Jerusalem,
By the gazelles or by the does of the field,
That you will not disturb or awaken my love
Until she pleases.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is this coming up from the wilderness
Like columns of smoke,
Perfumed with myrrh and frankincense,
With all the scented powders of the merchant?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
All of them are wielders of the sword,
Expert in war;
Each man has his sword at his side,
Guarding against the terrors of the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
King Solomon has made for himself a sedan chair
From the timber of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made its posts of silver,
Its back of gold
And its seat of purple fabric,
With its interior lovingly inlaid
By the daughters of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Go out, you daughters of Zion,
And look at King Solomon with the crown
With which his mother has crowned him
On the day of his wedding,
And on the day of the joy of his heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How beautiful you are, my darling,
How beautiful you are!
Your eyes are like doves behind your veil;
Your hair is like a flock of goats
That have descended from Mount Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your teeth are like a flock of newly shorn sheep
Which have come up from their watering place,
All of which bear twins,
And not one among them has lost her young.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your lips are like a scarlet thread,
And your mouth is beautiful.
Your temples are like a slice of a pomegranate
Behind your veil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your neck is like the tower of David,
Built with layers of stones
On which are hung a thousand shields,
All the round shields of the warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
Twins of a gazelle
That graze among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Until the cool of the day
When the shadows flee,
I will go my way to the mountain of myrrh
And to the hill of frankincense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You are altogether beautiful, my darling,
And there is no blemish on you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come with me from Lebanon, my bride,
You shall come with me from Lebanon.
You shall come down from the summit of Amana,
From the summit of Senir and Hermon,
From the dens of lions,
From the mountains of leopards.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
How beautiful is your love, my sister, my bride!
How much sweeter is your love than wine,
And the fragrance of your oils
Than that of all kinds of balsam oils!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
A locked garden is my sister, my bride,
A locked spring, a sealed fountain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your branches are an orchard of pomegranates
With delicious fruits, henna with nard plants,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nard and saffron, spice reed and cinnamon,
With all the trees of frankincense,
Myrrh, and aloes, along with all the finest balsam oils.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are a garden spring,
A well of fresh water,
And flowing streams from Lebanon.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Awake, north wind,
And come, wind of the south;
Make my garden breathe out fragrance,
May its balsam oils flow.
May my beloved come into his garden
And eat its delicious fruits!”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“I was asleep but my heart was awake.
A voice! My beloved was knocking:
‘Open to me, my sister, my darling,
My dove, my perfect one!
For my head is drenched with dew,
My locks with the dew drops of the night.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have taken off my dress,
How can I put it on again?
I have washed my feet,
How can I dirty them again?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My beloved extended his hand through the opening,
And my feelings were stirred for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I arose to open to my beloved;
And my hands dripped with myrrh,
And my fingers with drops of myrrh,
On the handles of the bolt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I opened to my beloved,
But my beloved had turned away and had gone!
My heart went out to him as he spoke.
I searched for him but I did not find him;
I called him but he did not answer me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Swear to me, you daughters of Jerusalem,
If you find my beloved,
As to what you will tell him:
For I am lovesick.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What kind of beloved is your beloved,
O most beautiful among women?
What kind of beloved is your beloved,
That you make us swear in this way?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My beloved is dazzling and reddish,
Outstanding among ten thousand.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
His eyes are like doves
Beside streams of water,
Bathed in milk,
And perched in their setting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His cheeks are like a bed of balsam,
Banks of herbal spices;
His lips are lilies
Dripping with drops of myrrh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His hands are rods of gold
Set with topaz;
His abdomen is panels of ivory
Covered with sapphires.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His thighs are pillars of alabaster
Set on pedestals of pure gold;
His appearance is like Lebanon,
Choice as the cedars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His mouth is full of sweetness.
And he is wholly desirable.
This is my beloved and this is my friend,
You daughters of Jerusalem.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where has your beloved gone,
O most beautiful among women?
Where has your beloved turned,
That we may seek him with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My beloved has gone down to his garden,
To the beds of balsam,
To pasture his flock in the gardens
And gather lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am my beloved’s and my beloved is mine,
He who pastures his flock among the lilies.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You are as beautiful as Tirzah, my darling,
As lovely as Jerusalem,
As awesome as an army with banners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn your eyes away from me,
For they have confused me;
Your hair is like a flock of goats
That have descended from Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your teeth are like a flock of ewes
That have come up from their watering place,
All of which bear twins,
And not one among them has lost her young.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your temples are like a slice of a pomegranate
Behind your veil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are sixty queens and eighty concubines,
And young women without number;
speaker: Narrator

text:
But my dove, my perfect one, is unique:
She is her mother’s only daughter;
She is the pure child of the one who gave birth to her.
The young women saw her and called her blessed,
The queens and the concubines also, and they praised her, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Who is this who looks down like the dawn,
As beautiful as the full moon,
As pure as the sun,
As awesome as an army with banners?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I went down to the orchard of nut trees
To see the plants of the valley,
To see whether the vine had grown
Or the pomegranates had bloomed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before I was aware, my soul set me
Over the chariots of my noble people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Come back, come back, O Shulammite;
Come back, come back, so that we may look at you!”
“Why should you look at the Shulammite,
As at the dance of the two armies?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How beautiful are your feet in sandals,
Prince’s daughter!
The curves of your hips are like jewels,
The work of the hands of an artist.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your navel is like a round goblet
That never lacks mixed wine;
Your belly is like a heap of wheat,
Surrounded with lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
Twins of a gazelle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your neck is like a tower of ivory,
Your eyes like the pools in Heshbon
By the gate of Bath-rabbim;
Your nose is like the tower of Lebanon,
Which looks toward Damascus.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
How beautiful and how delightful you are,
My love, with all your delights!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your stature is like a palm tree,
And your breasts are like its clusters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, ‘I will climb the palm tree,
I will grasp its fruit stalks.’
Oh, may your breasts be like clusters of the vine,
And the fragrance of your breath like apples,
speaker: Narrator

text:
And your mouth like the best wine!”
“It goes down smoothly for my beloved,
Flowing gently through the lips of those who are asleep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I am my beloved’s,
And his desire is for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, my beloved, let’s go out to the country,
Let’s spend the night in the villages.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let’s rise early and go to the vineyards;
Let’s see whether the vine has grown
And its buds have opened,
And whether the pomegranates have bloomed.
There I will give you my love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mandrakes have given forth fragrance;
And over our doors are all delicious fruits,
New as well as old,
Which I have saved for you, my beloved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh that you were like a brother to me
Who nursed at my mother’s breasts.
If I found you outdoors, I would kiss you;
No one would despise me, either.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Let his left hand be under my head,
And his right hand embrace me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Swear to me, you daughters of Jerusalem:
Do not disturb or awaken my love
Until she pleases.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who is this coming up from the wilderness,
Leaning on her beloved?”
“Beneath the apple tree I awakened you;
There your mother went into labor with you,
There she was in labor and gave birth to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Put me like a seal over your heart,
Like a seal on your arm.
For love is as strong as death,
Jealousy is as severe as Sheol;
Its flames are flames of fire,
The flame of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many waters cannot quench love,
Nor will rivers flood over it;
If a man were to give all the riches of his house for love,
It would be utterly despised.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“We have a little sister,
And she has no breasts;
What shall we do for our sister
On the day when she is spoken for?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If she is a wall,
We will build on her a battlement of silver;
But if she is a door,
We will barricade her with planks of cedar.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I was a wall, and my breasts were like towers;
Then I became in his eyes as one who finds peace.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
“You who sit in the gardens:
My companions are listening for your voice—
Let me hear it!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Hurry, my beloved,
And be like a gazelle or a young stag
On the mountains of balsam trees!”
speaker: Narrator
